message.content: We refer to the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines for reducing the risk of SIDS. The guidelines recommend placing infants to sleep on their backs on a firm, empty surface free of soft objects or loose bedding, using pacifiers after 1 month of age, and avoiding smoking during and after pregnancy. Bumpers, pillows, and blankets are not recommended as they may increase the risk of suffocation. Home apnea monitors are not recommended for routine use. Option (A) combines these recommendations and is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that infants should be placed on their backs to sleep, in a crib or bassinet without any soft objects (including blankets and pillows), and that parents should avoid smoking around the infant. The use of a pacifier after 1 month of age has also been shown to reduce the risk of SIDS. The use of bumpers, head propped up on a pillow, and wrapped in a warm blanket or infant sleeper are not recommended as they increase the risk of suffocation and SIDS. Home apnea monitors have not been shown to reduce the risk of SIDS and are not recommended for routine use.

Smoking during pregnancy or after the baby is born is also a risk factor for SIDS. Home apnea monitors are not recommended for routine use in healthy infants. Option A is the only one that includes all three of these recommendations.
